Text.valUnicode: View or add Contacts and Phone numbers.
Fill the XML file with data from the SQL Address Book.
Displays the raw XML internal data.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 You can view an XML file easily, by simply creating the same kind of browser task you would for any other data source.\par \par The trick is to select the Data Source entry that shows you the element you are interested in. Each complexType element will have its own Data Source entry. \par \par Also, if you enable the user to create new records, you have to ensure that these records are linked somehow to a parent record. The XML format simply doesn't allow "orphan" data.\par \par In this example, the View Contacts button allows you to view or add new Contact records.\par \par For each Contact, you can also view or add new Phone numbers, via a Subform.\par }

ExpSyntax.val: 'XM03: How Do I Create an XML View?'

Text.val: The Main Source in this instance is an XML file.
The file name is specified in the Main Source properties.
When a new record is created, a timestamp is used to create a unique record id.
When the Add Contact button is pressed, the program is switched to Modify
mode and then to Create Line. The alternative would be to have a separate program
to do more detailed data entry.
